title: 115_hr1884
content: The "Federal Firefighters Fairness Act of 2017" allows certain diseases to be presumed as work-related causes of disability or death for federal employees in fire protection activities. The "Federal Firefighters Fairness Act of 2017" amends the definition of 'employee in fire protection activities' to include specific roles and responsibilities in fire suppression and emergency response. The "Federal Firefighters Fairness Act of 2017" expands the definition of 'employee in fire protection activities' to include certain roles. It establishes presumptions for diseases related to fire protection activities, such as heart disease, lung disease, and specific cancers, if diagnosed within 10 years of the last active date of employment. These presumptions can be rebutted by evidence. The "Federal Firefighters Fairness Act of 2017" includes presumptions for diseases related to fire protection activities, such as heart disease, lung disease, and specific cancers like brain cancer, leukemia, and skin cancer. The Secretary of Labor can determine other cancers related to these hazards. The Act mandates the examination of health risks associated with firefighting and the submission of a report to Congress with analysis of injury claims, research on health risks, and recommendations for necessary actions. The amendment made by this section applies to an injury that is first diagnosed or a death that occurs, on or after the date of enactment of this Act.
